awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Autonomous Warning Triangle System (aWTS) for Emergency Stopping
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to ensure the secure transfer of goods and/or passengers in commercial motor vehicles (CMVs) and prevent the likelihood of secondary incidents when a commercial motor vehicles (CMV) has made an emergency stop on a highway. All CMVs need to comply with traffic safety regulations and deploy emergency warning devices (e.g., safety triangles) during an emergency stop. Without the presence of a human driver, an automated CMV should also be able to automate emergency warning device placement. Proper placement of these warning devices can be life-saving for drivers of non-automated vehicles on a highway. The proposed project will increase the safety of external drivers by preventing any secondary incidents associated with the lane/shoulder blockage due to a CMV malfunction and protect drivers of non-automated and/or semi-automated vehicles by assisting in the deployment of emergency warning triangles on highways. This project aims to remove barriers to higher-order automated technology adoption due to lack of standardization.

The project will result in the design, research, and development of an affordable, after-market, reliable, and safe autonomous Warning Triangle System (aWTS) to ensure the safety of the automated and semi-automated commercial motor vehicles (CMVs) during an emergency stop without requiring human assistance. aWTS consists of three low-cost autonomous triangle reflector devices which are planned to optimally fit in a charging dock/enclosure where they will be safely stored during stand-by mode. When activated by the emergency signal transmitted from the CMV, the autonomous triangles are designed to move successively to their pre-determined destinations on the highway. The research and development activity during this Phase I project includes, but is not limited to: reviewing safety codes and regulations, investigating different highway scenarios and associated challenges, and performing computer simulations; developing proof-of-concept hardware that can demonstrate the proposed system’s technical feasibility and its integration to automated CMVs; determining the optimal placement and assembly of the autonomous reflective triangles by collaborating with auto manufacturers; investigating the potential cyber-security risks to develop secure communications between CMV and aWTS; and identifying the operational challenges and the design targets while considering the cost of deployment, lifecycle costs, functional use, and interoperability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

The Autonomous Warning Triangle System (aWTS) project was developed to enhance roadside safety by automating the deployment of warning triangles during vehicular emergencies on highways. This system aims to reduce the risk associated with manual deployment, thus safeguarding human lives by decreasing the likelihood of secondary accidents.

Intellectual Merit

The aWTS project brought together a multidisciplinary team to tackle the challenge of developing a reliable autonomous system capable of operating under various traffic and environmental conditions. The project's intellectual merit is grounded in its innovative approach to integrating robotics, artificial intelligence, and traffic safety engineering:

  • Advanced Path Planning: We developed and refined several algorithms that enable autonomous navigation and optimal placement of warning triangles, considering real-time traffic conditions and road geometries.
  • System Integration and Robust Testing: The project successfully demonstrated the integration of hardware and software to achieve a functional prototype tested under controlled and real-world conditions.
  • Scalable Design: The design and development process focused on ensuring that the aWTS could be easily adapted for different vehicle types and sizes, promoting broader applicability and adoption.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of the aWTS project are significant in terms of societal benefits, economic savings, and environmental effects:

  • Enhanced Roadside Safety: By automating the deployment of warning triangles, the aWTS minimizes the need for human presence on highways during emergencies, significantly reducing the risk of injuries or fatalities.
  • Economic Efficiency: The system is designed to reduce traffic disruption caused by roadside incidents, which in turn can decrease economic losses related to traffic congestion and delays.
  • Environmental Benefits: Quicker resolution of traffic incidents also means less idling time for vehicles, which contributes to reduced vehicle emissions.

Project Outcomes

Throughout the life of the award, the aWTS project achieved several key outcomes:

  • Successful Prototype Development: The project culminated in the creation of a working prototype that demonstrated the feasibility of the concept through extensive testing.
  • Stakeholder Engagement and Feedback: Feedback from potential end-users and stakeholders has been overwhelmingly positive, indicating strong market interest and the potential for future commercialization.
  • Foundation for Future Innovation: The research and development conducted have laid a solid foundation for further innovation in autonomous roadside safety systems.

Last Modified: 05/28/2024
Modified by: Ece C Mutlu
